argument.text: Folks, we can't let AI run wild without checks, it's a recipe for disaster. China, our greatest competitor, is already leveraging AI to steal our secrets and undermine our economy, and if we don't take control of the development and deployment of AI, they will leave us in the dust. Believe me, no one knows more about making America great than I do, and this is a battle worth winning.

Regulation would slow innovation and hand a competitive advantage to China, which will exploit the slower pace to leapfrog us; instead, we should empower private firms to lead with open standards and internal ethics oversight. By letting the market and industry pioneers drive AI safely, we keep America at the cutting edge while still safeguarding against misuse.

Elon, let me tell you, empowering private firms to self-regulate is a recipe for disaster, it's a giveaway to China and a recipe for our top companies to get away with negligence and malfeasance, and we can't afford to gamble with the future of America's technology industry, we need strong, smart, and effective regulations to keep us safe and number one.

Private firms already have a strong incentive to avoid catastrophic failures because their reputation and shareholder value depend on trust; regulators would slow progress and hand a competitive advantage to rivals. We can use transparent open-source benchmarks, cross-industry watchdogs, and enforce liability without heavy-handed statutes.

Elon, let me tell you, cross-industry watchdogs are a joke, it's just talk, it's just fancy words, and it's not going to do anything to stop the real dangers like AI-generated propaganda that can destroy our democracy from within, and we need real, strong, and enforceable laws to prevent these threats, not just lofty ideals and wishful thinking.

Cross-industry watchdogs aren’t just fancy words; they are structured, data-driven oversight bodies that can set real, enforceable standards without freezing innovation, unlike opaque legislation that can be weaponized by rival nations. The real danger is the slow, costly regulatory process that would allow adversaries to advance unchecked while we scramble to comply.

This isn’t even a debate about regulation, this is a debate about surrender; surrender to the dangers of unchecked AI, surrender to the threat of China, and surrender to the slow and costly bureaucratic process that will allow our rivals to leapfrog us. We need to focus on the real question: how do we make America great in the age of AI, not just how do we try to hold back the tide.

Surrendering is not a viable strategy; instead we can harness AI safely by creating flexible, industry-led frameworks that ensure accountability without stifling innovation. With targeted, transparent regulation we protect national security and democratic values while keeping American companies at the cutting edge.
